timeline.message:
Issue #4321 Refactored Graceful shutdown

removed stopTimeout from all abstractLifeCycles.  It is on Graceful.LifeCycle, which is only implemented by components that can start a graceful shutdown (eg Server, ContextHandler and QueuedThreadPool)

Signed-off-by: Greg Wilkins <gregw@webtide.com>

timeline.bodyText: Don't use the _shutdown field directly here could throw NPE if the value can change to null.
timeline.author: lachlan-roberts
lachlan-roberts
lachlan-roberts

timeline.bodyText: AbstractHandlerContainer seems like a strange place to put the GracefulContainer interface and the shutdown static method. Why is this not done the way you did  Graceful.LifeCycle and have Graceful.Container.
timeline.author: lachlan-roberts
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -139,50 +141,51 @@ public void setServer(Server server)
             }
     }
 
-    /**
-     * Shutdown nested Gracefule handlers
-     *
-     * @param futures A list of Futures which must also be waited on for the shutdown (or null)
-     * returns A MultiException to which any failures are added or null
-     */
-    protected void doShutdown(List<Future<Void>> futures) throws MultiException
+    public interface GracefulContainer extends Graceful.LifeCycle, Container

replies.bodyText: Because org.eclipse.util.container does not know about Handlers... but yes it is a kind of strange place... I might make it top level.
replies.author: gregw

replies.bodyText: hmmm it no longer needs to know about Handlers!
replies.author: gregw

timeline.bodyText: This change is a little concerning, is this somehow related to the graceful shutdown refactor or just a cleanup?
timeline.author: lachlan-roberts

replies.bodyText: It is a minor change that allowed better debugging of graceful shutdown.  It allows the idle count to be maintained while the QTP is stopping
replies.author: gregw

timeline.bodyText: I don't understand why this value changed here? Doesn't seem anything to do with shutdown?
timeline.author: janbartel

replies.bodyText: the stopTimeout used to be an attribute on every AbstractLifeCycle. It no longer is, hence one less attribute.
replies.author: gregw

timeline.bodyText: Again, odd that this has nothing to do with shutdown. Perhaps you are missing a merge from jetty-10.0.x?
timeline.author: janbartel
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -44,9 +44,9 @@
      * The message displayed to the user when the server cannot be reached or
      * returns an error.
      */
-    private static final String SERVER_ERROR = "An error occurred while "
-        + "attempting to contact the server. Please check your network "
-        + "connection and try again.";
+    private static final String SERVER_ERROR = "An error occurred while " +
+        "attempting to contact the server. Please check your network " +
+        "connection and try again.";

replies.bodyText: I started getting checkstyle failures, so I had to fix this.  I think it was a problem with the merge of the change to apply checkstyle to tests?
replies.author: gregw

timeline.bodyText: The comment at line 40 should be for a CompletableFuture, not just a Future.
timeline.author: janbartel

timeline.message:
Issue #4321 Refactored Graceful shutdown

after review

Signed-off-by: Greg Wilkins <gregw@webtide.com>

timeline.bodyText:
Does this really need to be a CompleteableFuture rather than just a Future?
Would you ever expect the caller of this to complete the future or is it to be done internally like in the Shutdown utility with check().
timeline.author: lachlan-roberts

replies.bodyText: I guess the whole point of the API is that we don't know how the caller will wait for the shutdown to be complete... and it is possible to use a CompetableFuture as a Future, but not the other way around.
replies.author: gregw

timeline.bodyText: I think this should be the only line in the try/catch, otherwise if it throws the stopTimeout will never be set on the ThreadPool.
timeline.author: lachlan-roberts

timeline.bodyText: This logic seems wrong to me, we can never set the stopTimeout on the ThreadPool to longer than 1000ms, and if the Graceful.shutdown takes a full stopTimeout we could get a negative value for the ThreadPool stopTimeout.
timeline.author: lachlan-roberts
